source.raw_text:
The elbow plank (forearm plank) is an isometric, full-body exercise primarily targeting your core (transverse abdominis, rectus abdominis, obliques) for stability, while also engaging shoulders, back (lats, traps, rhomboids), arms (triceps, biceps), glutes, quads, and hip flexors, all working to maintain a rigid, neutral spine against gravity, building endurance for functional movements. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked (Isometric Contraction) 

• Core: Transverse Abdominis (deepest), Rectus Abdominis ("six-pack"), Obliques (sides). 
• Shoulders: Deltoids (stabilize), Serratus Anterior (shoulder blade stability). 
• Back: Latissimus Dorsi, Trapezius, Rhomboids (support spine). 
• Arms: Triceps (stabilize elbows), Biceps (assist). 
• Glutes & Hips: Gluteus Maximus (hip extension, alignment), Hip Flexors (pelvic stability). 
• Legs: Quadriceps, Hamstrings (keep legs straight and engaged). [2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11]  

Movement Pattern (Static Hold) 

• Type: Isometric exercise (muscles contract without changing length). 
• Action: Your body forms a straight line from head to heels, resisting gravity. 
• Key Focus: Deep core engagement to prevent sagging or arching of the lower back, maintaining a neutral spine. [1, 2, 7, 10]  

How It Works (Functional Movement) 
Planks build functional strength, making everyday activities like walking, carrying, and lifting easier by improving overall body tension and stability, especially for your core, which protects your lower back. [1, 6]
